keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Utah, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to five years to life in prison after appearing to fake his death and flee the U.S.

Rossi used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, and was identified through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit, which Utah authorities pursued as part of a broader effort to clear its rape kit backlog.

An online obituary in 2020 claimed Rossi died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which was later disputed by police, his former lawyer, and a former foster family, raising concerns about his disappearance and flight from justice.
Rossi was arrested in Scotland in 2021 while receiving treatment for COVID-19; hospital staff recognized his tattoos, including a Brown University crest, which matched an Interpol notice.
After a protracted legal battle, Rossi was extradited to Utah in January 2024 and sentenced in October 2025, with the judge calling him a 'serial abuser of women' and a 'flight risk'.
The victim described the trauma of being raped, including financial exploitation and emotional manipulation, and emphasized the need for accountability and safety.
Rossi did not testify during his trial and maintained his innocence, stating that the women were lying, despite being convicted by a jury.
He previously faced sex-related charges in Ohio and had a history of failing to register as a sex offender in Rhode Island, where he grew up and returned before faking his death.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah judge sentenced Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, to five years to life in prison for raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. Rossi, who had previously been wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender, was identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit and was later arrested in Scotland in 2021 after an Interpol notice recognized his distinctive tattoos. An online obituary claiming he died in 2020 was later disputed, leading to suspicion of a fake death and flight from justice. Rossi used aliases like Arthur Knight to evade capture and was found to have a history of financial exploitation and manipulation. He was convicted in both August and September 2025, with the second sentencing scheduled for November. The victim described the trauma and fear caused by the abuse, emphasizing the need for accountability and safety. Despite maintaining his innocence, Rossi was found guilty by jury. His case underscores the dangers of flight from justice, the importance of DNA backlog investigations, and the role of international cooperation in solving crimes.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
